utterances: And how do the countries in the region react to the president's enunciated policy to try and pivot U.S.
policy more to Asia?
Well, you know, this is a strategic, signature policy of the Obama administration.
And he got support on it from both South Korean and Japanese leaders.
China, of course, was not happy about the fact that they're not on the itinerary and that he is voicing support.
He is promising U.S.
protection for Japan in its administration of disputed islands in the East China Sea, but the response from China was fairly mild so far.
Of course, he wanted to make progress on this Trans-Pacific Partnership, the trade pact that is crucial to his Asia policy.
He could claim some progress, but no breakthroughs.
And I think there have been concerns in the region about the U.S.'s ability to maintain a focus - also, whether it has the economic wherewithal to maintain its commitments.
What's next on the president's agenda when he stops in Malaysia and the Philippines?
Well, Scott, maritime security issues will very much be at the top of his concerns.
Both Manila and Kuala Lumpur have territorial disputes with China in the South China Sea.
In Manila, he may sign an agreement to rotate more U.S.
troops through Philippine bases, and there will be some debate in the Philippines on whether the U.S.
is welcome back there.
And the president will also be trying to get Malaysia and the Philippines on board with the Trans-Pacific Partnership.
NPR's Anthony Kuhn in Seoul.
Thanks so much.
You're welcome, Scott.
OK, petro guzzlers, you've learned your lesson, haven't you?
You're ready to buy a Prius.
Sorry, too late.
They're all gone.
A Toyota dealer in Manassas, Virginia, is so desperate, it's offering a deal for customers who bought Priuses over the last few years.
The dealer will buy them back at the sales price, no questions asked.
So, if you cannot get a hybrid to buy, how about looking for a cheaper fuel?
A lot of people are doing that.
A recent Associated Press story described motorists in the Gaza Strip trying to make fuel with everything from cooking oil to pesticides and air fresheners.
We're not quite that desperate yet, but people are getting creative.
Here's NPR's Allison Keyes.
Some folk are willing to sacrifice a lot for things that are important to them.
James Baronschmidt (ph) of Severna Park, Maryland, is one of them.
When I'm going to groom my biodiesel, I first fill up the tank with used veggie oil, and then I just started heating up.
Watching Baronschmidt's process, it's clear that making one's own fuel is not for the impatient or the fainthearted.
He begins with a 30-gallon vat of used oil that he gets from a nearby Chinese-food restaurant.
Then...

We'll do the titration, where you basically test the level of acidity of the used veggie oil, and then based on the level of acidity, that determines how much potassium hydroxide you mix in with the methanol, before you - then in turn, mix that in with the heated-up used veggie oil.
Oh, it looks like coconut.
Yeah, but don't try to taste it.
Now, keep in mind, it is a poison.
You can get a little bit of it on your skin, but if you leave it on your skin long enough, it starts eating away at it.
Baronschmidt didn't do anything special to his car, except add a computer chip that increases his engine power.
But other drivers are doing more drastic things to their automobiles, and a Los Angeles-based company called Lovecraft Biofuels is helping them.
Owner Tacee Webb explains that they've converted close to 2200 diesel engines to run on other types of fuel, including 100-percent vegetable oil.
Our system is a one-tank system.
It utilizes the existing fuel tank, so you can put biodiesel, diesel, vegetable oil, including used vegetable oil, all in the same tank.
Webb says her company already has bustling offices in L.A.
and Portland, and the skyrocketing gas prices have business blooming at such a rate that they plan on opening stores in Austin, Texas, and in San Francisco, by the end of this year.
Their conversion kits run from 500 dollars for a do-it-yourself to about 1,000 if the company does it for you.
Webb says customers can both save money and do something for the environment.
It really puts fuel independence in the hands of the people, pump by pump.
Like, each time that you fuel up, you're making a choice of which fuel you use.
But you don't have to drive a diesel to cash in on some of the new technology out there.
The California-based E-Fuel Corporation plans to start shipments of a 10,000-dollar home ethanol system by the end of this year.
The company's vice president of biofuels, Floyd Butterfield, says the EFuel100 MicroFueler, is about the size of a stackable washer/dryer.

You'll put in feedstock in the machine, close the lid, press the button, and in a couple of a days, alcohol will start being accumulated in the tank, and you just take a hose like your regular hose at the gas station, and fill your car.
And what does that mean?
Carrell looks at lots of data on restraining orders, kid's test scores and their incomes when they grow up.
And he found that domestic violence has a big influence, not only on the kids in those families, but also on their classmates.
And like lots of problems in education, this issue - domestic violence - affects poor schools more than better-off schools.
So what can be done to improve things?
Carrell and his colleagues found one thing that really helps - parents reporting the domestic violence.
Things get better, not only for that family, but for all the child's classmates.
Carrell says there are three things that might account for this.
Number one, that violent person is now out of the kid's life.
Number two, another adult has decided to be proactive.
Three...
Good morning, Ms. Welch.
Good morning.
How was the weekend?
School counselors, like Welch.
Reporting domestic violence forces schools to pay attention, and school counselors get involved.
Welch talks to students about finding safe places in their homes.
She works on anger management, and she helps kids improve their emotional vocabulary.
Today, Welch is teaching a lesson in Vickie Fahed's kindergarten class.
...Because we're all on the same, what?
UNIDENTIFIED CHILD #2: Page.
UNIDENTIFIED CHILD #3: Team.
UNIDENTIFIED CHILD #4: Level.
Page, team, level.
You're right.
All those answers are right.
When Welch isn't in the classroom, Vickie Fahed sends angry or disruptive kids down the hallway to see Welch.
The child comes back so relaxed and so at peace.
When that kid is at ease, the whole class can focus.
That translates into higher test scores and better graduation rates.
All this is great, but only on the days when Welch is there.
You can tell when she's not here in this building.
It's a big difference because we're like, OK, today's not - she's not here today.
We have to wait till tomorrow.
Brett Welch knows she can't help every child, but she says she does what she can.
You tell them that you love them because you do and because maybe that's what they need to be able to get through whatever there is to get through at home.
And if that child's home life gets better, things will get better at school for that child and all their classmates, too.
Gabrielle Emanuel, NPR News.
In New York City, the Muslim community is worried.
People want answers about the fatal shooting of a local imam and his assistant.
A suspect has been arrested and charged, but as NPR's Hansi Lo Wang reports, police have not announced a motive.
It's been almost a week of mourning for the families of Imam Maulama Akonjee and his associate Thara Uddin, including Uddin's sister-in-law Afia.
Our family is still deeply saddened, and we hope that the authorities are able to bring the murderer to justice.
The Imam's son-in-law Momin Ahmed says they still want to know the motive.
They caught him.
We're kind of happy a little bit, but we want to know what's the main reason for killing the two person.
Both the imam and his assistant were shot in the backs of their heads as they left their mosque in Queens on Saturday.
Oscar Morel, a 36-year-old man from Brooklyn, has been charged with five criminal counts, including first degree murder.
But local Muslim leaders say they want prosecutors to charge these deaths as a hate crime.
Here's Debbie Almontaser of the Muslim Community Network.
They are by product of a growing anti-Muslim and anti-immigrant sentiment fueled largely by the bigoted rhetoric and fear mongering emanating from the current presidential election campaigns.
If convicted, Morel faces up to life in prison without parole.
A hate crime charge would not make his sentence any harsher, says former Manhattan prosecutor Mark Bederow.
There's nothing to add to the sentence.
It just doesn't make sense given the strong case for first degree murder that they appear to have here.
Bederow says it's hard to prove a person's motive for a hate crime and says adding one could complicate the prosecutor's trial strategy.
Michael Fanning once served as a detective sergeant on the NYPD's Hate Crimes Task Force.
He says there can be consequences for not charging a hate crime when a specific community feels like it's being attacked on purpose.
